Abstract 1 Emerging chemical contaminants (ECCs) represent newly identified chemical 2 contaminants which have not been covered by routine monitoring and regulatory programs. 3 Current research into ECCs is greatly hindered by the shortage in analytical methods due to 4 the complex sample matrices, extremely low environmental levels, and the “emerging” nature 5 of ECCs. Use of nanomaterials (NMs) to solve the analytical problem of ECCs is a very 6 active research field. We have published a review paper summarizing the application of 7 nanomaterials in analysis and monitoring of ECCs in 2014. In recent years, this field kept 8 rapidly developing with many new materials and technologies emerging. This paper reviews 9 recent progress in this filed. Different types of NMs and analytical techniques are covered. 10 Notably, we pay special attention to the newly developed materials, such as metal-organic 11 frameworks (MOFs), upconversion materials, carbon dots, and titania (TiO2) nanoparticles. 12 We also stress the progress in emerging techniques such as surface-enhanced Raman 13 spectroscopy (SERS) and laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (LDI-TOF MS). 14 Finally, we discuss current challenges and future prospects in this field. 15 16 Keywords: Emerging chemical contaminant; Nanomaterial; Environmental analysis; 17 Metal-organic framework; Upconversion; Sample preparation; Surface-enhanced Raman 18 spectroscopy; Mass spectrometry; Review 19 20

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 1
sections.text:
The use of chemicals has increased tremendously with the growth in economics and 2 prosperity in recent decades. The term “chemicalization” describes the increasing use of 3 chemicals and the resulting environmental chemical contamination. Although the use of 4 hazardous chemicals has continually been restricted, the total discharge amount of chemicals 5 into the environment does not decline evidently, because new chemicals are synthesized and 6 used instead all the time. A large number of new chemicals have been found in environmental 7 media and to pose the characteristics of environmental contaminants, such as potential 8 biotoxicity, bioaccumulation, and persistence in the environment. However, most of them 9 have not been covered by standard monitoring and regulatory programs. To differ from 10 traditional chemical contaminants, they are termed as “emerging chemical contaminants 11
(ECCs)” by the scientific community. 1-3 The ECC family includes a large diversity of 12 chemicals, e.g., pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs), hormones, 13 perfluorinated compounds (PFCs), flame retardants, industrial additives, disinfection 14 by-products (DBPs), perchlorate, algal toxins, etc. 4 15
To date, knowledge of the occurrence of ECCs in the environment is still limited. 5-8 16 Reliable ecotoxicological data are available for only a small fraction of ECCs. A serious 17 bottleneck in ECCs studies is the lack of proper analytical methods. The difficulties in the 18 analysis of ECCs lie mainly in the complexity of environmental matrices, the extremely low 19 environmental levels of ECCs (usually at ppb to ppt levels), and their “emerging” nature. 4 In 20 spite of the great efforts made in the development of analytical methods for ECCs in recent 21
years, challenges still remain for most of ECCs. 3, 9 The current analysis of ECCs in 22

environmental samples is predominantly based on liquid or gas chromatographic separations 1 (LC or GC) and mass spectrometric (MS) detection. Prior to analysis, rigorous sample 2
pretreatment procedures are required, which are however laborious and time-consuming. 10 3 The low throughput of these methods also greatly limits their application in environmental 4 health and exposomics studies. Thus, it is highly desired to develop new methods for the 5 analysis of ECCs. 6 Due to the unique physical and chemical properties, nanomaterials (NMs) have been 7
widely used in various fields. 11-13 The use of NMs in analytical methods also represents an 8
increasing trend in environmental analysis. 14, 15 Specifically, NMs have shown great 9 potentials to be used as promising tools to solve the analytical issue of ECCs. For example, in 10 sample preparation, NMs can be used as nanoabsorbents to replace traditional adsorbents 11
owing to their high surface areas and high affinity for chemical contaminants. 16, 17 For 12 electrochemical detection, NMs can be used as highly efficient electrode materials or 13
catalysts due to their exceptional photoelectric properties and size effects. 18, 19 Apart from that, 14 matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) is also an 15
important application aspect of NMs. 20 With strong optical absorption, excellent 16 energy-transfer efficiency and high chemical and physical stability, NMs can be used as novel 17 MALDI matrices to extend the range of targeted analytes from biopolymers to small 18
molecules. 21-23 In 2014, we have published a comprehensive review paper which summaries 19 the applications of NMs in analysis and monitoring of ECCs. 4 In last three year, we notice 20 that this field continued to undergo rapid development, especially in the following aspects: 21 (1) More NMs have gained new applications in the analysis of ECCs, e.g., metal-organic 22

frameworks (MOFs), upconversion materials, carbon dots, and TiO2 nanoparticles; 1 (2) New technologies (e.g., surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and 2 MALDI-TOF MS) have been used more frequently in analysis of ECCs; 3 (3) More types of ECCs can be analyzed by NMs-based analytical methods; and 4 (4) More NMs-based methods have been applied in studying real environmental 5 systems. 6 In this article, we review recent progress in application of NMs in analysis of ECCs, 7 especially for the progress since 2014. We discuss the properties of several typical NMs used 8 in environmental analysis and particular attention is paid to the newly developed materials. 9 We then summarize the applications of NMs in determination of ECCs in terms of different 10 analytical techniques, such as sample preparation, electrochemical sensing, fluorescence 11 detection, colorimetric detection, SERS, LDI-TOF MS, etc. It should be noted that we do not 12 strictly limit to ECCs, and some representative methods toward traditional chemical 13 contaminants are also included. We also discuss current challenges and give our perspectives 14 in this field. Last but not least, we should keep in mind that NMs themselves are considered 15 as a type of ECCs, and the use of NMs should also be regulated and controlled within a safe 16
extent. 14, 24-26 17

sections.heading: 2.1. Common nanomaterials 19
sections.text:
A great variety of NMs have gained different degrees of success in analysis of ECCs. In 20 our last review, 4 we have introduced in detail four kinds of common NMs, including carbon 21 NMs, Au nanoparticles (Au NPs), magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs), and quantum dots (QDs). 22

In recent applications, these materials continued to play important roles in analysis of ECCs. 1 Some new carbon NMs have emerged derived from their original forms by chemical 2
modifications, such as oxidation, 27, 28 sulfonation, 29-31 and fluorination. 32-34 New analogues of 3
carbon NMs, such as graphynes, 35-40 graphene oxide nanoribbons (GONRs), 27, 41 ordered 4
mesoporous carbon, 42, 43 and carbon nitride nanosheets, 44-47 have attracted increasing interest 5 owing to their extraordinary physical and chemical properties. For ordered mesoporous 6
carbon, its size-selective adsorption ability is used to selectively enrich low-mass ECCs. 48, 49 7 For magnetic NMs, some novel materials were prepared such as carbon nitride 8
nanosheets-supported silica-coated magnetic nanoparticles 44, 45, 50 and hybrid magnetic 9
CoFe2O4 nanoparticles. 51 For nonmagnetic NMs, titanium, copper and zinc oxides were 10 prepared and applied in electrochemical sensing and SERS detection of ECCs in addition to 11 normally used Au and Ag nanoparticle-based substrates. 12 Besides the NMs above-mentioned, several novel types of NMs have also shown their 13 tremendous application potentials in analysis of ECCs in recent years, including MOFs, 14 upconversion materials, carbon dots and TiO2 nanoparticles. Herein we give a detailed 15 introduction on these materials. 16

sections.heading: 2.2. Metal-organic frameworks 17
sections.text:
MOFs have been applied in analysis of ECCs due to their large surface areas, 18 three-dimensional (3D) extended porous structure, excellent optical sensitivity, and structural 19
and chemical tunability. 52-56 MOFs are infinite crystalline lattices formed by incorporation of 20 metal ions into organic molecule ligands. The structure of MOFs is flexible and adjustable 21 depending on different metallic component vertices and organic linkers. The synthetic 22

approaches of MOFs are rather diverse, among which one-pot solvothermal method is 1
commonly used due to its ease to operate. 53-55 Regarding to environmental analysis, the poor 2 stability in aqueous solution of MOFs is a great challenge. To overcome this problem, some 3
water-stable MOFs have been synthesized, 57 which can maintain stable over relatively long 4 periods of time over a wide pH range. 5 Besides MOFs, covalent-organic frameworks (COFs) are another emerging class of 6 crystalline porous polymers with atomically precise designed and highly ordered organic 7
building blocks. 58-60 Similar to MOFs, COFs also have periodic and porous nanostructures 8 and large surface areas, making COFs excellent candidates as sorbent materials or 9
components in designing nanodevices for analysis of ECCs. 10 2.3. Upconversion nanomaterials 11 Upconversion NMs, mainly consisting of lanthanide (Ln), yttrium (Y), and scandium (Sc) 12
compounds, have recently attracted widespread attention. 61 One of their most attractive 13 properties is that they can emit light with shorter wavelengths than those of the excitation 14 light. That is to say, it is possible to obtain visible light by near infrared irradiation with 15
upconversion NMs. 61, 62 Therefore, this type of materials are suitable for application in in site 16 and non-destructive biosensing, optical imaging, and photodynamic therapy. A key to use 17 upconversion NMs is to overcome the limitation of low luminescence efficiency by choosing 18 appropriate host materials. Halides (e.g., fluoride, chloride, and bromide) were used to 19
effectively enhance upconversion luminescence efficiency. Yb 3+ -Er 3+ or Yb 3+ -Tm 3+ co-doped 20
NaYF4 (e.g., NaYF4:Yb 3+ , Er 3+ ; NaYF4: Yb 3+ , Tm 3+ ) are the most commonly used 21 upconversion NMs owing to their high refractive index and high transparency. Different 22

8
strategies have been developed for synthesis of upconversion NMs, such as thermal 1
decomposition, hydrothermal reaction, and ionic liquids-based synthesis. 63 In analysis of 2 ECCs, the surface of upconversion NMs usually needs to be modified by functional groups 3 such as silica, polymers, molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs), aptamers, proteins, DNA, 4
biomacromolecules, etc. 61-63 These functionalizations can be achieved by ligand engineering, 5 ligand attraction, surface polymerization, self-assembly, and layer-by-layer assembly 6
technologies. 61-63 7 2.4. Carbon dots 8 Carbon dots are a new type of carbon-based NMs. They have been shown to be suitable 9 for bioimaging, disease diagnosis, catalysis, and photovoltaic devices owing to their chemical 10 inertness, low toxicity, good biocompatibility, water solubility, high photostability, and low 11
cost. 64, 65 Carbon dots can be synthesized by top-down or bottom-up routes. The top-down 12 approach is to break the large carbon structures to generate carbon dots. Carbon nanotubes 13 (CNTs), graphite, activated carbon, and nanodiamonds can be used as candidate carbon 14 sources. The bottom-up approach requires a molecular precursor subjected to 15 combustion/thermal treatments. Citrate, carbohydrates, and polymer-silica nanocomposites 16
have been reported as available molecular precursors. 66, 67 Nevertheless, naked carbon dots 17 have low quantum yields because of their unstable surface defects that reduce the ability of 18 radiative recombination. Thus, surface passivation and functionalization are usually needed to 19 reduce the harmful effects of carbon dots. Polymers, e.g., poly(propionyl 20 ethyleneimine-co-ethyleneimine) (PPEI-EI) and PEG1500N, are commonly used as surface 21
passivating agents by forming insulating layers at the surface of carbon dots. 65 22

sections.heading: 2.5. TiO2 nanoparticles 1
sections.text:
TiO2 nanoparticles can be used in different forms, i.e., powder, crystals, and thin films. 2 TiO2 nanoparticles can be prepared by sol-gel, microemulsion, precipitation, hydrothermal, 3
solvothermal, electrochemical, and biological strategies. 68-70 Liquid-phase method is most 4 commonly used because of its convenience and ease to control. In the synthesis, it is essential 5 to control the shape and size of TiO2 nanoparticles by sol-gel or microemulsion processes. 6 TiO2 nanoparticle have been widely used in photovoltaics, photocatalysis, photochromics, 7
and sensors due to their excellent optical properties. 70, 71 The applications have also been 8 extended to the detection and removal of chemical contaminants. 9

sections.heading: 3. Recent applications of nanomaterials in detection of emerging chemical 10
sections.text:
contaminants 11 3.1. Sample preparation 12 In addition to traditional solid-phase extraction (SPE) and solid-phase microextraction 13
(SPME), 4 micro-solid-phase extraction (µ-SPE) 72, 73 has recently sparked much research 14 interest because of its low cost and automation. Magnetic solid-phase extraction (MSPE) is 15 another important technique in sample preparation. NMs provide promising tools to facilitate 16 these techniques. The typical applications are introduced beneath and also listed in Table 1. 17 3.1.1. Use of carbon nanomaterials in sample preparation 18 Carbon NMs are the most popular NMs in environmental analysis. In recent years, 19 different strategies were developed to modify and functionalize carbon NMs to overcome the 20 hydrophobicity of the surface or to improve their stability and solubility in aqueous 21
solutions. 74, 75 These strategies include oxidation, 28, 76, 77 amination, 78-81 carbonylation, 78, 82 22

hybridization or modified with specific hydrophilic moieties, such as ionic liquids, 83 silica, 76 1
TiO2, 84 polymers, 50, 77 and bismuth vanadate (BiVO4). 85 The resulting composite NMs offered 2 effective tools for the analysis of drugs, phthalates, and endocrine disruptors in environmental 3 samples. 4 Another recent trend in this area is the increasing use of molecular dynamics simulation 5 tools to explore the adsorption mechanisms and to predict the affinity of different molecules 6 for NMs. By using these tools, the performance and adsorption coefficients of chemical 7
contaminants on activated carbon, charcoal, CNTs, and graphene could be predicted. 75, 86-89 8 Speltini et al. used amino-terminated alkyl-functionalized multi-walled carbon 9 nanotubes (MWCNT-R-NH2) as a SPE sorbent for the detection of perfluorooctanoic acid 10 (PFOA) and perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS) followed by ultra-performance liquid 11 chromatography-electrospray tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-ESI-MS) in surface 12
waters. 90 Patiño et al. used MWCNTs, carboxyl-functionalized MWCNTs (MWCNT-COOH), 13 amino-functionalized MWCNTs (MWCNT-NH2), and nitrogen-doped CNTs (N-CNTs) as 14 sorbents to extract three different types of compounds (i.e., a chlorinated paraffin 15 1,8-dichlorooctane, a quinolone nalidixic acid, and an alkylphenoletoxilate 16
2-(4-methylphenoxy)ethanol). 78 Comer et al. applied naked and hydroxylated CNTs for the 17 adsorption of 30 small aromatic compounds with a variety of functional groups and also 18 predicted the adsorption equilibrium constants by theoretical computation (Figure 1). Among 19 different modified forms of graphenic carbon, the polyvinylpyrrolidone conjugation showed 20 the highest affinity and could be selected as an efficient adsorbent for sequestration of 21
atrazine. 91 22

For graphene, commercially available GO, 92 colloidal GO nanoparticles, 93 GO-based 1
hydrogels, 94 ionic liquids-GO composites, 83 and thermo-responsive GO-perylene 2
bisimides-containing poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) hybrid 95 were developed for the 3 adsorption of drugs, phthalates, and organic pollutants from water samples. GO is commonly 4 used as a starting material to synthesize other graphene-based composite adsorbents. 5 Al-Khateeb et al. reported a method that graphene nanoplatelets were directly used as an 6 adsorbent to remove aspirin, caffeine, and acetaminophen from Red Sea water, waste water, 7
and tap water. 96 Sun et al. prepared a miniaturized self-assembled graphene pipette-tip 8 solid-phase extraction (PT-G-SPE) cartridge, and then the cartridge was used coupled with 9 liquid chromatography-fluorescence detection (LC-FD) to enrich and detect three 10
sulfonamide antibiotics in environmental water samples. 97 Chen et al. developed an approach 11 to remove sulfamethoxazole and ciprofloxacin from water samples using GO as an 12
adsorbent. 98 13 For graphene-based composites, Speltini et al. prepared a hybrid material consisting of 14 silica microparticles modified with graphene (RGO-silica). The RGO-silica was used as a 15 mix-mode sorbent for pre-concentration of fluoroquinolones in water samples based on SPE 16 followed by HPLC-FD detection. The method was applied in real environmental water 17
analysis with a detection limit (LOD) of 5 ng/L. 76
Zhuang et al. applied a regenerable TiO2 18 nanotube/reduced graphene oxide (rGO-TON) hydrogel to improve the performance of 19
adsorption and removal of ciprofloxacin from aqueous solutions. 84 Chen et al. explored the 20 multiple adsorption mechanisms of nitro-aromatic compounds on GO, reduced graphene 21 oxide (RGO), and graphene nanosheets by infrared spectroscopy technique, demonstrating 22

that π-π electron donor-acceptor interactions, charge electrostatic, and polar interactions were 1
responsible for the adsorption. 89 2 3.1.2. Use of MOFs in sample preparation 3 Inspired by their porosity structure and excellent adsorption capacity, MOFs have been 4 developed as sorbents for sample preparation of ECCs in different techniques including SPE, 5
SPME, MSPE, and µ-SPE. 72, 73 As mentioned above, since the prerequisite for the application 6 of MOFs in environmental analysis is the stability in water, several water-stable MOFs were 7 prepared to meet this requirement, such as ZIF-8, ZIF-67, MIL-100(Fe), and UiO-66(Zr), in 8 extraction of phthalate esters, drugs, endocrine disrupting compounds, and other 9
contaminants. 53-56, 99 10 Liu et al. used Fe-MIL-53 as a sorbent for preconcentration of four phenolic EDCs in 11 fruit juices and milk samples based on the strong π-π stacking interaction. The target 12 contaminants were detected by high-performance liquid chromatographic-ultraviolet 13 detection (HPLC-UV) with the LODs of 0.05-0.10 ng/mL for fruit juice and 0.10-0.20 ng/mL 14
for milk samples. 100 15 Dai et al. developed a novel method to extract four sulphonamides from environmental 16 water followed by UPLC-MS/MS analysis. MIL-101 was used as a SPE adsorbent due to the 17 large specific surface area, high porosity, and excellent chemical stability. Under the 18
optimized conditions, the LODs of the target analytes could reach 0.03-0.08 µg/L. 101 19 MOFs could also be integrated into a SPME monolithic column. Lirio et al. fabricated 20 an aluminum-based MIL-53-organic polymer monolithic column and applied it as an SPME 21 sorbent for the extraction of trace amount of penicillins in river water and milk. synthesis of core-shell nanocomposites with a magnetic Fe3O4 core and a COF shell. 103 A 8 highly stable porous COF, TpBD (Tp and BD refer to 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol and 9 benzidine, respectively), as a shell showed fast adsorption of typical environmental 10 endocrine-disrupting chemicals, bisphenol A (BPA) and bisphenol AF (BPAF) in aqueous 11 solutions. 12 3.1.3. Use of magnetic nanomaterials in magnetic solid-phase extraction 13 MSPE has been wildly applied in enrichment and removal of ECCs. The development of 14 magnetic nanoadsorbents is a highly active research area. Recently, magnetic Fe3O4 15 functionalized with β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) and C3N4 was applied in analysis of ECCs based 16
on host-guest recognition and hydrophobic interactions. 104 The magnetic particles are 17 typically encapsulated with silica or polymer shells to prevent from being oxidized and also 18
to facilitate further modification. 45, 104-107 Ionic liquids, 108 MIPs, 50 MOFs 109 have been used to 19 functionalize magnetic materials. 20 Zhou et al. synthesized MWCNTs coated with magnetic amino-modified CoFe2O4 21 (CoFe2O4–NH2) nanoparticles and used them as adsorbents for the adsorption of 22

GC/MS. The LODs were at ppb levels. 110 22

Surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy 6 SERS is a promising “fingerprint” technique for environmental analysis owing to its 7 simplicity, rapidness, excellent sensitivity, good selectivity, and non-destructive properties. 8 The research on SERS mainly focuses on the exploration of SERS substrates. In addition to 9 normally used Au and Ag NMs, TiO2 nanoparticles and GO were recently explored as SERS 10
substrates. 145 11 Chen et al. fabricated a 2D silver nanofilm-coated porous anodic aluminum oxide 12 material (AAO) and used it as a SERS-active substrate in the detection of CAP in food 13 samples. The material showed an excellent enhancement effect for the SERS signals with an 14 enhancement factor of approximately 2 × 10 4 . The sensor was applied in quantification of 15
CAP in milk with the LOD of 7.5 ppb. 146 16 Zhang et al. used gold@silver core-shell nanorods (Au@Ag NRs) to develop a rapid and 17 straightforward method for simultaneous SERS determination of two pesticides (thiram and 18 methamidophos) in apple samples. The LODs were 0.46 µM for thiram and 440 µM for 19
methamidophos. 147 20 Yang et al. developed a method to real-time and in situ monitor pesticide penetration by 21 SERS mapping based on the Au NPs substrate. They monitored the penetration of two 22

sections.heading: 3.6. Laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry 10
sections.text:
MALDI-TOF MS provides a simple and high-throughput tool for analysis of 11 biopolymers and large organic molecules. However, when it is applied to analysis of small 12 molecules, strong matrix interference in low-mass region is usually observed. To overcome 13 this problem, NMs, especially carbon NMs, have been explored as novel MALDI matrices 14 due to their strong optical absorption properties, high energy-transfer efficiency, and high 15
chemical stability to produce few ion fragments in low-mass region. 99 This makes the 16 high-throughput analysis of small molecules by MS possible. Furthermore, surface-enhanced 17 laser desorption/ionization (SELDI), a variant mode of MALDI-TOF MS, has recently 18
attracted much research interest. 52, 58, 59 This technique uses a probe for extraction, enrichment, 19 desorption, and ionization of target analytes, thus greatly simplifying the analytical 20 procedures and enhancing the sensitivity. NMs have been demonstrated to be useful probes 21 for SELDI-TOF MS. 22

Liu et al. prepared graphene oxide nanoribbons (GONRs) by one-step and one-pot 1 pressurized oxidation of MWCNTs. Such a novel variety of graphene with high 2 length-to-width ratio and straight edges, as a matrix or probe in MALDI or SELDI MS, could 3 produce significantly higher MS signals than other carbon NMs and allowed simultaneous 4 detection of multiple small molecules (e.g., 2,2’,4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether (BDE-47), 5 estradiol, and TBBPA) in complex samples. The method was applied in screening of ECCs in 6
wastewater treatment plant samples. 27 7 To further improve the specificity of GONRs-based SELDI probe, Wang et al. 8 functionalized GONRs with an antibody using polyethylene glycol (PEG) as a linker (see 9 Figure 7). The antibody could specifically bind the target analytes and the PEG could 10 maintain the steric structure and activity of the antibody after it was bound to GONRs. This 11 antibody-GONRs conjugate provided a highly selective and sensitive SELDI probe to detect 12
chloramphenicol in river water and human serum samples. The LOD could reach 10 pg/mL. 41 13 Wang et al. developed a two-step strategy for MALDI-TOF MS screening of low-mass 14 hazardous compounds in complex samples. In the first step, order mesoporous carbon was 15 used to selectively extract low-mass compounds while excluding the interference from large 16 molecules in sample matrix. In the second step, the analytes were eluted from order 17 mesoporous carbon and analyzed by MALDI-TOF MS with graphene as a matrix. The 18 method was successfully applied in rapid screening and identification of unknown toxic 19
substances such as perfluorochemicals in human serum samples. 42 20 Huang et al. further investigated the use of order mesoporous carbon as a new MALDI 21 matrix and SELDI probe in detection of trace amount of toxic chemicals in complex samples. 22

With CMK-8 as a SELDI probe, they successfully identified and screened six perfluorinated 1 compounds in a single drop of human whole blood without any complicated sample 2 preparation procedures. The method provides a promising tool for high-throughput analysis 3
of MS. 43 4 Recently, Huang et al. prepared fluorographene (FG) by one-step exfoliation of 5 fluorographite. Based on the unique structure and self-assembly properties, FG was used as a 6 MALDI matrix and SELDI probe with higher sensitivity and better reproducibility than other 7 graphene-based materials. They showed the use of FG as a SELDI probe in quantification of 8 bisphenol S in paper products and high-fat canned food samples as well as in identification 9
and screening of quaternary ammonium halides in sewage sludge samples. 32 10 Min et al. prepared a gas-phase N-doped graphene (gNG) by a modified thermal 11 annealing method. The as-prepared material was used as a matrix for analysis of anabolic 12 androgenic steroids and anticancer drugs in negative ion MALDI-TOF MS. With the 13 advantages of excellent salt tolerance and high sensitivity, the method provided a useful tool 14
for analysis of complex biological samples. 152 Rao et al. also used N-doped graphene QDs 15 (N-GQDs) as a matrix to detect perfluoroalkyl sulfonates and other small molecules in 16
environmental samples by MALDI-TOF MS. 153 17 Apart from graphene, other 2D nanosheets were also used as SELDI probes in analysis 18 of small molecules. Liu et al. synthesized a water-stable 2D MOF nanosheet (Zn2(bim)4, bim 19 = benzimidazole) by ultrasonic liquid exfoliation. By combining the advantages of MOFs and 20 2D nanosheets (e.g. good solubility, superior electronic and photonic properties), the material 21 could be applied as a clean-background MALDI matrix for analysis of small biomolecules 22

The nitroaromatics in 19 groundwater could be transported and accumulated in the mesophyll by the plant, which 20 subsequently resulted in relative changes in emission intensity. sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and perspectives 2
sections.text:
Nanoscience/nanotechnology is currently one of the fastest developing fields. The 3 mushrooming of new NMs greatly promotes the advance in analytical science. In this article, 4 we have reviewed recent progress in application of NMs in analysis of ECCs. It can be 5 clearly recognized that NMs are taking more and more prominent parts in development of 6 analytical methods for ECCs. In a wide range of analytical techniques, NMs have shown their 7 superior capabilities over conventional materials in enhancing sensitivity and selectivity of 8 detection, reducing analytical time and sample consumption, and enabling miniaturization of 9 the analytical devices. From the recent progress, we can learn that this field has shown the 10 following clear trends: 11 (1) More NMs are finding their positions in the analysis of ECCs. In the past, it usually 12 took a long period of time to recognize the application potential of a new material in 13 environmental analysis after it was synthesized and applied in other fields. This situation has 14 now changed a lot because more and more analytical chemists have realized the great value 15 of NMs in analytical chemistry. 16 (2) The designing and functionalization of NMs becomes more elaborate. In most cases, 17 multiple components or functional groups are integrated into the nanoadsorbents or 18 nanoprobes to make the materials versatile in different aspects of analysis (e.g., separation, 19 enrichment, and detection). 20

(3) More modern analytical techniques (e.g., microextraction, microfluidics, 1 nanoelectrodes, high-resolution and high-throughput mass spectrometry) are used together 2 with NMs to better fulfil the requirements for the analysis of ECCs. 3 (4) More stress on the analytical ability of complex samples. The methods are usually not 4 only validated with artificial spiked samples, but also need to be applied in different types of 5 real world samples. 6 Undoubtedly, NMs have provided powerful analytical tools for the research on ECCs. 7 Nevertheless, we should also be aware of the current challenges remaining in this field. Most 8 of these new tools are still used only in lab and cannot be immediately put into practical 9 applications. To solve this problem, in future studies, more efforts should be made in the 10 following aspects: 11 (1) Standardization and commercialization of NMs. The reproducibility for the synthesis 12 of NMs in different batches and from different labs is still a serious problem. Small difference 13 in the properties of NMs may lead to proportionally large deviations in analytical results. 14 Thus, it is urgent to push on the standardization of NMs to give more confidence to the 15 analytical results obtained by NMs-based methods. It is also highly desired that more NMs 16 should be commercially available so that one can easily obtain NMs to use them in the 17 analysis of ECCs. 18 (2) Reducing the cost of NMs. Synthesis and purification of NMs is still not an easy task 19 in most environmental labs. However, compared with traditional materials, the high cost of 20 commercial NMs greatly reduces their attractiveness. It is also very important to increase the 21 reusability and recyclability of NMs to make them more cost-effective. 22

(3) More practical application-oriented method development. Despite the delicate 1 designing of NMs, their performance in practical use is usually not as good as expected 2 mainly due to insufficient consideration of environmental affecting factors (e.g., salinity, 3 dissolved organic matter (DOM), pH, temperature, etc.). Thus, the method development 4 should be more practical application-oriented to fill the gap between the method developers 5 and method users regarding to ECCs. 6 (4) More consideration of requirements in modern environmental science. Elucidation of 7 the relationship between environmental pollution and human health has become an important 8 objective of modern environmental science. This raises a tremendous demand in analytical 9 methods capable of in situ, in vivo, real-time, non-destructive, micro-volume, or 10 high-throughput analysis of complex samples. NMs will definitely make a great contribution 11 to achieve these goals. 12 13 Acknowledgements 14 The authors acknowledge financial support from the Chinese Academy of Sciences (No. 15 XDB14010400, QYZDB-SSW-DQC018) and the National Natural Science Foundation of 16 China (No. 21377141, 21422509, 21337002).
